text: Patient: Now I go for -I go for pulmonology tests, I think it’s tomorrow, maybe Thursday. Thursday, and but I don’t see a pulmonologist until early March, second of March. Doctor: Yeah. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we call that micro metastatic cancer. Patient: All right. Doctor: Has spread somewhere else, but it’s so tiny, microscopic that we cannot find it on the scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And in the past we did have two areas that lit up on the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: We had the bone scan and you had both of those areas radiated at the same time as getting the hormone therapy. Patient: Correct. Right. Doctor: So it’s possible that those would not be visible at this time. Or it’s possible that they still might be visible and it’s also possible that new areas you know might have popped up somewhere else in different bones or different areas like lymph nodes which were not there before. So it’s very important you know once the PSA reaches one that we basically establish what the extent of your cancer is at that point in time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, um, the standard recommendation for you at that point would be to go back uh on a hormone therapy. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Patient: Well, I have some relatives in Germany. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And, uh- Family Member: Yeah. If they’re still there. (Laughter) Patient: Pardon? Family Member: If you can get on, on the study, which would involve the scan, doing the scan? Doctor: Doing the scan first. Family Member: Yeah. Of course. text: Patient: This is experimental? Doctor: Correct. Yes. Patient: And uh so I would take the BET1 inhibitor and keep on the Xtandi? Doctor: That’s correct. Patient: And the Lupron? Doctor: So that’s an option. Okay? The other option is do we go now to the medications based on your BRCA mutation should we start you on Lynparza which is one of the medications that are basically given for BRCA mutation patients with prostate cancer. Okay. Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is --

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
